contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=November 2010}} '''Cumberlandite''' is the [[U.S. state]] of [[Rhode Island]]'s [[List of U.S. state minerals, rocks, stones and gemstones|state rock]].<ref>[http://www.ri.gov/facts/factsfigures.php Fun Facts and Figures about Rhode Island]</ref> It is only found in large concentrations on a {{convert|4|acre|m2|adj=on}} lot in [[Blackstone Valley]], [[Cumberland, Rhode Island|Cumberland]], and in traces scattered throughout the [[Narragansett Bay]] watershed. Due to its high amounts of [[iron]], it is slightly [[magnetic]]. [[Image:Cumberlandite.JPG|thumb|right|Two pieces of Cumberlandite]] The rock was formed over 1.5 billion years ago by [[volcano|volcanic]] activity. The rocks were discovered by settlers hundreds of years ago, and were initially deemed valuable for the manufacture of [[cannon]] and farm tools in the 18th and 19th centuries. The rock also contains a relatively high level of [[titanium]], also valuable for the manufacture of tools. Colonists tried to make cannon from the rock during the [[American Revolutionary War|Revolutionary War]], but the cannon cracked because of the weakness of the iron.{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}} Cumberlandite weathers to a brownish black with white crystals. This is strikingly different from the weathered look of other rocks in Rhode Island's glacial deposits. It is also much denser than the granites and metamorphic rocks that are common in these deposits. The rock is common in glacial deposits just south of its source location, and can be found in deposits all the way to the southern shore of Narragansett. This combination of coming from only one location, being obviously different from other rocks, and being easily identified by members of the public all may have led to its being selected as the Rhode Island state rock. ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord|42|00|17.5|N|71|27|13|W|type:landmark_region:US-RI|display=title}} [[Category:Petrology]] [[Category:Geology of Rhode Island]] [[Category:Symbols of Rhode Island]] {{Petrology-stub}} {{Rhode-Island-stub}}
